policy: ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) in Higher Education
description: Federal law requiring colleges to provide reasonable accommodations for students with disabilities
reasonable_accommodations: Extended time on exams (typically 50% or 100% extra time)
Reduced course load (12 units = full-time for financial aid)
Alternative exam formats (oral exams, take-home exams)
Housing accommodations (accessible dorms, single rooms, emotional support animals)
documentation_required: Medical documentation from licensed professional (doctor, psychologist, etc.) describing disability and functional limitations
registration_process: Register with campus disability services office (typically called Disability Resource Center, Office of Accessible Education, etc.)
cost: Free (colleges must provide accommodations at no cost to student)

description: Federal law prohibiting discrimination based on disability in programs receiving federal funding
applies_to: All colleges receiving federal funding (virtually all colleges)
key_provision: No otherwise qualified individual with a disability shall be excluded from participation in, be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination
504_plan: Accommodation plan developed with disability services office
difference_from_ada: Section 504 applies to federally funded programs; ADA applies more broadly

eligibility: Students with learning disabilities, ADHD, anxiety, processing disorders, physical disabilities affecting writing speed
documentation_required: Psychoeducational evaluation or medical documentation showing need for extended time
implementation: Student takes exam in separate room (disability services testing center) with extended time
notes: Most common accommodation. Typically 50% extra time, but can be 100% for severe disabilities.

description: Students with disabilities can take fewer than 12 units and still be considered full-time for financial aid
eligibility: Students with disabilities that limit ability to take full course load (chronic illness, mental health conditions, physical disabilities)
documentation_required: Medical documentation from doctor explaining why reduced course load is necessary
financial_aid_impact: Student is considered full-time for financial aid purposes (Pell Grant, loans, scholarships) even with reduced course load
approval_process: Disability services office provides letter to financial aid office confirming reduced course load accommodation
notes: This accommodation is critical for students with disabilities who cannot handle 12+ units. Allows them to receive full financial aid while taking fewer classes.

description: Housing accommodations for students with physical disabilities, medical conditions, or mental health needs
types_of_accommodations: Wheelchair-accessible dorms (roll-in showers, wider doorways, accessible bathrooms)
Single rooms (for medical conditions requiring privacy, sleep disorders, mental health)
Air conditioning (for medical conditions exacerbated by heat)
documentation_required: Medical documentation from doctor or mental health professional explaining need for accommodation
cost: Single room premium may apply (typically $2,000-$5,000/year extra), but some schools waive premium for disability accommodations
esa_vs_service_animal: Service animals (trained for specific tasks) are allowed under ADA. ESAs (provide emotional support) are allowed under Fair Housing Act but not ADA. ESAs require documentation from mental health professional.

policy: COA (Cost of Attendance) Adjustment for Disability Expenses
description: Colleges can increase COA to include disability-related expenses, which increases financial aid eligibility
allowable_expenses: Medical expenses not covered by insurance
process: Student requests COA adjustment from financial aid office with documentation of disability expenses
impact_on_aid: Higher COA = higher financial aid eligibility (can receive more grants/loans to cover disability expenses)
example: Student with $60k/year personal care attendant cost can request COA increase from $85k to $145k, allowing $60k more in financial aid
notes: COA adjustment is discretionary (financial aid office decides). Requires documentation of actual expenses.

policy: Professional Judgment for Disability Medical Expenses
description: Financial aid offices can use professional judgment to exclude disability medical expenses from income
scenario: Family pays $60k/year for personal care attendant (not tax-deductible). Financial aid office can exclude this $60k from income, reducing EFC.
process: Student submits professional judgment appeal with documentation of medical expenses
impact_on_aid: Lower income = lower EFC = more financial aid
notes: Professional judgment is discretionary. Not all schools will grant appeals. More likely at schools with generous financial aid policies.

description: State-run program providing funding for college and disability-related expenses for students with disabilities
administering_agency: State VR agencies (each state has its own VR agency)
eligibility: Individual with disability that is a barrier to employment, and VR services will help achieve employment goal
application_process: Apply through state VR agency (process varies by state, can take 3-6 months)
cost: Free (VR services are free for eligible individuals)
income_limits: Some states have income limits; others do not
notes: VR can be a game-changer for students with disabilities. Can cover tuition, attendant costs, equipment, etc. Must show that college degree will lead to employment.

description: Federal disability benefits for low-income individuals with disabilities
monthly_benefit_notes: $914/month federal (2025); some states add supplement (CA adds $200 = $1,114/month)
asset_limit_notes: $2,000 asset limit (can use ABLE account to save more without affecting SSI)
income_limit: SSI reduces $1 for every $2 earned above $85/month
student_earned_income_exclusion: First $2,290/month of student earned income is excluded (2025 limit), up to $9,230/year
impact_on_fafsa: SSI is untaxed income - must report on FAFSA
able_account: Can save up to $18,000/year in ABLE account without affecting SSI
notes: SSI + student earned income exclusion allows students with disabilities to work part-time and attend college while receiving SSI.

policy: SSDI (Social Security Disability Insurance) and College
description: Federal disability benefits for individuals who worked and paid into Social Security
asset_limit: No asset limit for SSDI (unlike SSI)
income_limit: Substantial Gainful Activity (SGA) limit: $1,550/month (2025). Earning above SGA can terminate SSDI.
student_exception: No specific student earned income exclusion for SSDI (unlike SSI)
impact_on_fafsa: SSDI is untaxed income - must report on FAFSA
notes: SSDI is for individuals who worked before becoming disabled. Less common for college students (more common for adult students returning to college).
Stanford has excellent disability services. Campus is mostly accessible. Strong support for students with disabilities.

UC Berkeley has one of the best disability services programs in the country. Strong advocacy for students with disabilities. Campus has some hills (challenging for wheelchair users) but accessible routes available.
Michigan has strong disability services. Campus is mostly accessible. Cold winters can be challenging for students with mobility disabilities.

policy: Medical School Technical Standards and Disability Accommodations
description: Medical schools have 'technical standards' (essential functions) that students must meet, with or without accommodations
accommodations_available: Medical schools must provide reasonable accommodations (extended time, assistive technology, etc.)
accommodations_not_required: Medical schools do NOT have to waive essential functions (e.g., cannot waive requirement to perform physical exams)
disability_types: Blind/low vision students: Can use assistive technology, may need accommodations for visual tasks
Deaf/hard of hearing students: Can use sign language interpreters, assistive listening devices
Mobility disabilities: Can use wheelchairs, may need accommodations for procedures requiring standing
Learning disabilities: Can receive extended time, note-takers
controversy: Technical standards can be barrier for students with disabilities. Some argue standards are too rigid; others argue they ensure patient safety.

description: Scholarship for students with disabilities pursuing computer science or related fields
eligibility: Student with disability (visible or invisible), pursuing CS/engineering degree, demonstrate leadership
notes: Competitive scholarship for students with disabilities in tech fields. Includes invitation to Google Scholars' Retreat.

description: Scholarship for students with disabilities pursuing STEM degrees
eligibility: Student with disability, pursuing STEM degree, demonstrate financial need and leadership
notes: Renewable scholarship for students with disabilities in STEM. Includes mentorship opportunities.

policy: Emotional Support Animals (ESA) in College Housing
description: Students with mental health disabilities can request ESA in dorms under Fair Housing Act
legal_basis: Fair Housing Act (not ADA - ESAs are not service animals)
eligibility: Student with mental health disability (depression, anxiety, PTSD, etc.) for whom ESA provides therapeutic benefit
documentation_required: Letter from licensed mental health professional (therapist, psychiatrist, psychologist) stating: (1) student has mental health disability, (2) ESA is necessary to alleviate symptoms, (3) professional's credentials
process: Submit ESA request to disability services or housing office with documentation
restrictions: ESA must be well-behaved, cannot pose threat to others, student is responsible for care and damage
cost: No pet deposit required (ESA is accommodation, not pet), but student liable for any damage
notes: ESAs are increasingly common on college campuses. Proper documentation is key. ESAs are NOT allowed in classrooms or dining halls (only housing).
